Example

The deer population in a forest is estimated to drop by \(7â‹…3%\) each year. Each year, \(20\) deer are introduced to the forest. The initial deer population is \(200\).

  1. How many deer will there be in the forest after \(3\) years?
  2. What is the long term effect on the population?

Solution

  1. To answer this question, we find the values of \(u_1,u_2,u_3\) from the recurrence relation as we have seen previously. In this case we have \[ \begin{align*} &u_{n+1} = 0.927u_n + 20; \\ &u_0 = 200 \\ &u_1 = 0.927 \cdot 200 + 20 =205.4 \\ &u_2 = 0.927 \cdot 205.4 + 20 =210.4058 \\ &u_3 = 0.927 \cdot 210.4058 + 20 = 215.0461. \end{align*} \] Thus, there are \(215\) deer after three years.
  2. In order to see what the overall long term effect on the deer population is, we have to calculate the limit of the sequence. Firstly, note that a limit exists because \[ -1 < 0.927 < 1. \] Therefore we can calculate the limit as \[ L= \frac{b}{1-a} = \frac{20}{1-0.927} = 273.97 \] to 2 d.p. This tells us that the deer population will settle around \(273\).
